DOC.HEAD: Man With A Grenade Interrupts Christmas Mass in Bucharest
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A man armed with a hand grenade was captured outside Bucharest's main Mitropolia cathedral during Christmas service Monday after worshipers shouted that he was a terrorist. The patriarch of the Romanian Orthodox Church, Teoctist Arapasu, was preparing to address hundreds of worshipers who braved sporatic gunfire to attend the service when the man, who carried an identification card from the hated Securitate secret police, was spotted. A woman and some other people started shouting, ``We know this man, he's a terrorist.'' Two soldiers and a group of civilians who acted as security in front of the church jumped on the man, opened his raincoat. They showed he was wearing a bulletproof vest and was armed with a hand grenade. The man, taken away by soldiers armed with automatic rifles, did not resist. The soldiers took the documents from the man and a Securitate identification card. In the church, Arapasu thanked about 500 worshipers for coming to the service despite the battles between a new government and forces loyal to deposed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu was reported captured Saturday with his wife, Elena, as the tried to flee a popular uprising. State radio announced the Ceausescus were executed Monday after a secret trial at which they were convicted of genocide and plundering of $1 billion in public funds. The partiarch asked people to pray for ``the brave young people who have given their lives in the struggle against Ceausescu's terrorist regime.'' ``We must thank God, who gave us freedom after 25 years of terror,'' the patriarch told the congregation. ``Many of our church services were banned by the terrorist regime. We must not let this happen again.'' The patriarch also thanked hundreds of people who brought presents and food to the church in memory of the dead. ``I have been waiting 40 years for this. Now I can openly go to church,'' said Ion Ganescu, a dissident who spent 10 years in prison for his opposition to Ceausescu.
